The way I am figuring things, FL is trading at about 30% less than what they would get if they sold all assets and paid all liab... I think Benjamin Graham called this the 'breakup value" of a company. Total Assets- Total liab= about 2.4 billion dollars...today the mkt cap of FL is 1.905 Billion... I am seeing this as incredibly undervalued by almost any measure. Time to buy... Thoughts?

I expect FL to move back towards its 20 day exponential moving average of $46.46 over the next two weeks. FL was up about 4% in November after its competitor DKS had a positive ER. Read this "Foot Locker Slips Despite a Thorough Earnings Beat — Buy the Dip"In June of this year, Smart Investing editor Charles Payne declared that FL stock is a traditional-retailing investment on a genuine comeback trail. Specifically, Payne cited management’s efforts in revitalizing the brand. He stated that “keys going forward will be continued shedding of non-performing stores, selling premium products and managing inventories effectively.”

FL had a $1.8 billion in cash at 6/30/21 no? Isn’t that more than enough for the two acquisitions ? Plus they have long term investments of say $700-800 million which is largely the GOAT investment. So we are looking at say $2.6 billion between the cash and investments and no debt at 6/30/21. Plus the company probably earned a boat load in the quarter ending today no? School season, people exercising in the summer? I’d think the CEO saw the 20 point drop in the stock as a buying opportunity. I would hope he sees it this way. Hopefully GPS sees it that way too. Does BAC analyst think he or she is the first person to figure out the NKE issues affect FL? Genius! To think this analyst get paid nearly $1 million a year plus restricted stock. Pathetic. Happy to see them hit the stock today on old news. Bought more and hopefully it gets hit more so I can keep buying. The BBBY news should affect FL at all. Shouldn’t affect GPS either. Totally different businesses. FL should probably take on debt at a few percent interest before taxes to buy back stock. Why not?

In a recent update on second-quarter fiscal 2020, management highlighted the huge response to the company’s assortment as stores started reopening. This could be attributed to pent-up demand and the effect of the fiscal stimulus that aided in-store sales and drove continued momentum across the digital channel. Notably, comparable-store sales jumped nearly 18% for second-quarter fiscal 2020.Management further cited that significant sales coupled with disciplined cost control aided the company to revert to positive earnings per share despite gross margin being stressed by a channel mix shift and elevated promotional backdrop. Apparently, management envisions adjusted earnings per share in the range of 66-70 cents for the quarter ended Aug 1.Including pre-tax charges of about $19 million associated with winding down of the Runners Point banner and the restructuring of Eastbay, as well as costs of $18 million incurred for the social unrest, earnings per share are likely to fall in the band of 38-42 cents per share compared with 55 cents recorded in the year-ago period.
